Potential Activity for use by teacher in preparation for visit of guest instructor:

In advance of the guest instruction, Students will create a set of Artist Trading Cards (white cardstock that measures 2.5 x 3.5 inches or 64 X 89 mm) in which they will choose a medium of their choice to demonstrate their knowledge of each of the seven art elements. Determine the commonalities within a group of artists or visual images attributed to a particular type of art, timeframe, or culture

Visualize and hypothesize to generate plans for ideas and directions for creating art and design that can affect social change.

Advice/Resources:

A successful approach would be to provide the classroom teacher with a case study for the students to work on two weeks in advance and create a list of questions for the students to answer related to the case study. The teacher can then put these questions into a google form or similar document whose output can be shared with the guest instructor two days in advance. This allows the guest instructor to be able to see the answers and call on the specific students or groups providing interesting answers in advance. Then in class structure the lesson where you, the guest instructor, first asks the students to share their solution to the case study you provided, engage in discussion and debate with them over their solution before sharing in a more traditional lecture format how you or your company solved this problem using data analytics.

The guest or other student plays the role of the homeowner who is required to make a decision amongst the three choices. The student playing the role of the plumber is given the attached sheet which explains the three different choices, the cost of each alternatives and the added value the customer receives for each option.

Lesson Summary: How do the concepts of supply and demand curves impact a real world business and what strategies can a business adopt to compete effectively within an industry subject to strong supply and demand curves?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • have seen real world supply and demand curves at work in the business world of the guest instructor
  • be aware of the strategies adopted by companies to compete within an industry with strong supply and demand curves and what actions a business can take when supply or demand curves shift with either a positive or negative impact on their business
  • know what are major factors or determinants that cause the supply and demand curves within the guest instructors industry to shift either to the left or right
  • EXTENSION TOPIC: see how government policies like price floors, subsidies, fiscal or other government policies impact the supply and demand curves in their industry.
Lesson Educational Standards:
AP College Board Microeconomics:

The Nature and Function of Product Markets, Supply and Demand. Market equilibrium, Determinants of supply and demand, Price and quantity controls, Elasticity (price, income and cross-price elasticities of demand, price elasticy of supply) Consumer / producer surplus, allocative efficiency, Tax incidence and deadweight loss.


MN State Standard Substrand 4: 5. Individuals, businesses and governments interact and exchange goods, services and resources in different ways and for different reasons; interactions between buyers and sellers in a market determines the price and quantity exchanged of a good, service or resource.


NCSS: Markets exist when buyers and sellers interact. This interaction determines market prices and thereby allocates scarce goods and services.

  • Prices send signals and provide incentives to buyers and sellers. When supply and demand change, market prices adjust, affecting incentives.
  • Competition among sellers lowers costs and prices, encouraging producers
  • 44 National Standards for Social Studies Teachers Disciplinary Standards to produce more of what consumers are willing and able to buy. Competition among buyers increases prices and allocates goods and services
Short Description: Demand and supply is a model economists use to show how a market behaves. Demand deals with consumers, supply deals with producers.

Lesson Title: Suspension and Arch bridge construction judge
Lesson Summary: Have a local civil engineer review, give feedback and judge the model suspension and arch bridges created by students. The engineer will also share information about their daily work and why they like working in a STEM based career.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
In this lesson, a guest instructor from the the civil engineering or architecture industry will come to class to:

  • evaluate the arch and suspension bridges created by students
  • give feedback to students on their design process and final product
  • share insights about what it is like to work in the civil engineering or architecture industry
  • explain how they would address the challenge of building a model bridge given their engineering experience

 

In advance of this lesson the classroom teacher will have had students build their own suspension and arch model bridges and will contact the guest judge to describe the specific challenge given to the students. There are many lesson plans available to assist teachers in having students build model suspension and arch bridges.

An exemplary example is available at the teachengineering.org website called Construction Technologies: Create the Strongest Bridge  

2013 by Regents of the University of Colorado; original 2005 Worcester Polytechnic Institute
Short Description: Have a civil engineer or architect come to class to review, give feedback and judge the bridges your students have created.

Lesson Title: Using Social Media in a corporate communications strategy
Lesson Summary:
• What purposes does social media serve in an organizations overall communications strategy?
  • What writing skills are essential for social media?
  • How do organizations tailor their social media to audiences?
  • How do organzations create a social media strategy, including platform considerations and preplanned posting?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Learning Objectives. Students will learn:

  • When and how to design social media to get feedback from an audience or to persuade an audience
  • How to distinguish between formal and informal writing and understand what qualities make each effective
  • How organizations write clearly, precisely and persuasively on social media
  • What role images play in social media; what is the relationship between image and persuasion.
  • How social media can be used to tell a story
  • How organizations assess their social media posts and overall strategy


 Resources: 

  • 12 Quick Editing Tips for Social Media: https://blog.hootsuite.com/editing-tips-social-media-managers/
  • Why Every High School Should Teach a Social Media Class: https://medium.com/an-idea-for-you/why-every-high-school-should-teach-a-social-media-class-c777b6e6eef9
  • How Social Media Can Help Teach Good Writing: https://www.edsurge.com/news/2017-10-31-how-social-media-can-help-teach-good-writing


 Tips:

  • Give an overview of your social media strategy to students to provide context. They are often unaware of the complex thinking and advance planning that companies employ for social media.Consider showing them documents/actual plans that show aspects of your strategy.
  • Explain how you learn about your audiences.
  • Explain how even though social media posts are often brief, much thought and revision goes into writing on platforms
  • Explain what analytics you use to assess social medias effectiveness
Short Description: What is the role social media plays in a corporate communication and marketing strategy?

Lesson Title: Writing with clarity and conciseness in the professional world
Lesson Summary: What role does clarity play in all kinds of writing: persuasive, informational, business, academic, personal, etc.? What factors influence clarity in writing? What effect does sentence clarity have on readers? Why is it important to be able to write concisely in a professional settingHow does one write with conciseness?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Learning Objectives: Students will learn:

  • key elements that make writing clear (strong active verbs, no dangling modifiers, avoiding prepositional phrase pileup, clear pronoun refs, etc)
  • how to revise writing for clarity
  • What makes for clear writing in different fields (i.e. medicine vs. business v. science)
  • What is conciseness in writing and how to revise writing for conciseness


Resources: Clarity in writing: https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/general_writing/mechanics/sentence_clarity.html 


Conciseness in writing: https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/general_writing/academic_writing/conciseness/index.html 


Good one-page resource on strong verbs: http://writing2.richmond.edu/writing/wweb/clarity.html 


Six-Word Stories Bring Clarity and Focus to Businesses

https://medium.com/@storytellermark/six-word-stories-bring-clarity-and-focus-to-businesses-755ddc3d69b4 


Writers Diet: http://www.writersdiet.com/test.php. Online automated feedback tool / writing analysis to help declutter writing. Instructors would need to explain relevance to students, perhaps model with their own writing first. Does not provide fixes but still very interesting. Highlights parts of speech in a writing sample & gives writing a leanness rating. Could have students run their own writing through and discuss with a partner, think of what to do w/info. Purpose of the test, according to its creator: The purpose of the test is modest: to alert writers to some of the sentence-level grammatical features that most frequently weigh down academic prose. Zombie nouns by Helen Sword: how making verbs into nouns clutters your writing / big words arent always better: https://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/23/zombie-nouns/ Fun zombie nouns video: Beware of nominalizations (AKA zombie nouns) Helen Sword  


Tips:

  • Show students examples of cluttered writing before and after revising. Could have them list questions that come up with unclear writing / what is reader confused about?
  • Have students read something from instructors field & discuss what makes it clear (or not)
  • Know that students may struggle to identify elements of a sentence / may need modeling.
  • Compare example of a verbose piece of writing and then a more concise and clear version of the same piece of writing.
Short Description: The critical importance of writing with clarity and conciseness in the professional world
